item.title: Homemade Marathons
item.description: For me, the marathon was a rare, rare moment when the city seemed truly whole; when people came together—for free—to watch an event, and they cheered the back-of-the-pack plodders as enthusiastically as they did the whippets who led the way. I was so moved by it that I was choked up for most of the twenty-six miles, seeing this crazy display of community and generosity.
item.dc:creator: Susan Orlean

item.title: Two if by Sorrow: Boston and Its Losses
item.description: The bombs that went off near the finish line at this year’s Boston Marathon have so far taken the lives of three people, one of them an eight-year-old boy named Martin Richard. More than...
item.dc:creator: Jill Lepore

item.title: The Patriots’ Day Bombing
item.description: Even if you grew up in Massachusetts, which I did, Patriots’ Day is one of those holidays that take you by surprise. It’s a state holiday (also celebrated in Maine, which was once part...
item.dc:creator: Louis Menand

item.title: The Meaning of the Boston Marathon
item.description: Perhaps it was someone who spotted a terribly easy target. Or perhaps it was someone who saw a reflection of the human spirit and decided to just try to shatter it.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Thompson

item.title: Boston Marathon: Video from the Scene
item.description: Ever since the development of reliable photographic techniques, and photographer Matthew Brady’s work during the Civil War, tragedies have been linked to iconic images. They are both a record of what happened and a...
item.dc:creator: Alex Koppelman

item.title: After the Boston Marathon Explosion
item.description: At the corner of Clarendon Street and Stuart Street, near Copley Square, a woman screamed the name Lisa at intervals, panic on her face as she walked back and forth. Runners, many wrapped in...
item.dc:creator: Ian Crouch

item.title: An Explosion at the Boston Marathon
item.description: The end of a marathon is a soft target. The scene is always chaotic. Runners are delirious. And today, in Boston, though we don’t know what caused it—an accident, a deliberate act—there was horror.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Thompson

item.title: Who Said What
item.description: This is a complicated story, but here goes. Eleven years ago, for The New Yorker, I wrote a review of a biography of Primo Levi called “The Double Bond,” by Carole Angier. Levi, an...
item.dc:creator: Joan Acocella

item.title: The Crisis in a Nutshell: Quotes of the Week
item.description: A digest of the past week’s prophetic and interpretive thought.
item.dc:creator: Aswini Periyasamy

item.title: What About Denise?
item.description: A few weeks ago, students at Harvard’s Graduate School of Design started a petition for Denise Scott Brown be “retroactively acknowledged for her work deserving of a joint Pritzker Prize.”
item.dc:creator: Gareth Cook

item.title: Lucky Guys
item.description: The legend of Mike McAlary—tabloid chronicler of the crime-ridden, crack-laden New York City of the Koch-Dinkins era—has been burnished twice over: first by the man himself, who, at various times, dominated the crime pages of Newsday, the Post, and the Daily News, and again by Nora Ephron, whose stage biography Lucky Guy, starring Tom Hanks as McAlary, has just opened on Broadway.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schulman

item.title: A Note on the New York Radical Feminists
item.description: After my article about Shulamith Firestone (“Death of a Revolutionary”) ran in The New Yorker last week, I got a nice e-mail from Alix Kates Shulman, the author of “Memoirs of an Ex-Prom Queen,”...
item.dc:creator: Susan Faludi

item.title: A Great Cold War Movie
item.description: John Le Carré’s article fills in the cause of that grief’s special intensity: Martin Ritt’s sense of betrayal as the norm of political life and all of Richard Burton’s troubled relations to himself got poured into one of the most truthful and emotionally resonant movies made in the entire Cold War period.
item.dc:creator: David Denby

item.title: Shauna Lyon: Chez Sardine in the West Village review.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">The restaurateur and University of Wisconsin alum Gabriel Stulman’s clutch of downtown Manhattan restaurants, a.k.a. Little Wisco, includes the neighborhood haunts Joseph Leonard and Jeffrey’s Grocery, the trendy cocktail den Fedora, and the excellent, more rarified Perla. To this commonwealth, Stulman has recently . . .
item.dc:creator: Shauna Lyon

item.title: Sean Wilsey: Among the gondoliers of Venice.
item.description: Shortly before dawn, not so long ago, I stood in the stern of a small boat in the Venetian lagoon. I was rowing with a single oar, facing forward, heading west. Floodlights on the wharves of the mainland chemical plants, six miles away, glowed in front of me. I crossed . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Sean Wilsey

item.title: Sasha Frere-Jones: The Joy Formidable at the Music Hall of Williamsburg.
item.description: Neither the pop charts nor the indie community is big on power trios who write carefully, land hard, and don’t slouch—so, of course, we’ve got one now. The Joy Formidable’s leader is the Welsh singer and guitarist Ritzy Bryan, who formed the . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Sasha Frere-Jones

item.title: Robyn Schiff: “Gate.”
item.description:
Everyone has a cousin Benjamin Bunny. Peter said a walk would do him good. The edge of the wood. Peter did not enjoy himself anymore. He never would again. The brooding lettuces in their falcon hoods. The coppice gate
wound shut by weeds, the jaws of life trying to keep . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Robyn Schiff

item.title: Roberto Bolaño: “Mexican Manifesto.”
item.description: Laura and I did not make love that afternoon. In truth, we gave it a shot, but it just didn’t happen. Or, at least, that’s what I thought at the time. Now I’m not so sure. We probably did make love. That’s . . .
item.dc:creator: Roberto Bolaño

item.title: Peter Schjeldahl: An Elizabeth Peyton show at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise.
item.description: Elizabeth Peyton polarizes people. Some deplore her small, swiftly and tenderly brushed or drawn portraits of celebrities and friends, based mostly on photographs, as trivially sentimental. Others thrill to the self-abandon of her enraptured regard. What else in contemporary art is so whole-hearted? A big show of little . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Peter Schjeldahl

item.title: Peter Schjeldahl: Amsterdam remakes its signature museums.
item.description: Queen Beatrix, of the Netherlands, walks an orange carpet this week to reopen the Rijksmuseum, in Amsterdam. It’s a big deal. The jewel in the crown of the nation’s cultural institutions, where you can see major works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, and their cohorts of the seventeenth . . .
item.dc:creator: Peter Schjeldahl

item.title: Michael Robbins: “Günter Glieben Glauchen Glöben.”
item.description:
Says here to burn the rich and take their shit. I’m paraphrasing. I’m barely grazing the surplus. Do the rich have inner lives, like little lambs and Antigone? They never give me their money.
Bill Gates, the great humanitarian, stands upon a peak in Darien. I . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Michael Robbins

item.title: Lizzie Widdicombe: Arianna Huffington and Anne Sinclair have a chat.
item.description: Arianna Huffington was at home the other night, in her new Mercer Street loft. Mozart was playing on a sound system, and the giant room was mostly empty, except for flowers and a few clumps of Italian furniture. She was hosting a dinner party for the Huffington Post’s . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Widdicombe

item.title: Joan Acocella: New works by Mark Morris.
item.description: One thing that Mark Morris knows how to do is to create an ambiguity that feels like clarity. Often in his work, a person, after doing something that you think you understand, does something that utterly contradicts that. Or he goes on doing his thing, but someone at the side . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Joan Acocella

item.title: Jennie Erin Smith: Life, death, and tourism in the Darién Gap.
item.description: The Pan-American Highway runs sixteen thousand miles, from Anchorage to Tierra del Fuego, with one significant interruption: an expanse of rain forest along the border of Colombia and Panama. The road ends abruptly on the Panama side, just north of a national park, and picks up again as a . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Jennie Erin Smith

item.title: James Surowiecki: David Stockman’s moment.
item.description: It’s been a great couple of weeks for David Stockman. Granted, he’s been called “unhinged,” “nonsensical,” and “a cranky old man,” after arguing in the Times that the current bull market is a huge bubble, and that America’s . . .
item.dc:creator: James Surowiecki

item.title: Ian Johnson: In China, the world’s biggest movie lot gets even bigger.
item.description: Today, the Palace of the Qin King, an austere complex with curved roofs, red pillars, and a grand entrance of ninety-nine steps, rises amid the green mountains of southern China. Two thousand years ago, it was nestled in the scrubby hills of the north, where its occupant became the . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Ian Johnson

item.title: Hendrik Hertzberg: Margaret Thatcher’s mixed legacy.
item.description: By the dismal end of the nineteen-seventies, a series of oil shocks had sent the economies of most of the world’s developed democracies into a tailspin. Their publics were not pleased. In country after country, voters voted out the ins and voted in the outs. Ideology didn . . .
item.dc:creator: Hendrik Hertzberg

item.title: Goings on About Town: The Theatre
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPENINGS AND PREVIEWS<!--/goatcategory--> Please call the phone number listed with the theatre for timetables and ticket information.
<!--goatTitle-->THE ASSEMBLED PARTIES<!--/goatTitle--> For Manhattan Theatre Club, Lynne Meadow directs this play by Richard Greenberg (“Take Me Out”), set in 1980 and 2000, about a Jewish . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Readings and Talks
item.description: goatTitle-->“POETRY & THE CREATIVE MIND”<!--/goatTitle--> Mario Batali, Patricia Clarkson, Stew, Kathleen Turner, and many others read and discuss their favorite poems in an evening benefitting the Academy of American Poets. The New Yorker writer Calvin Trillin is the master of ceremonies. (Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: On the Horizon
item.description: THE THEATRE OLD IS NEW April 30 The seventy-five-year-old avant-garde playwright Richard Foreman founded his Ontological-Hysteric Theatre in 1968 to produce his own plays, which came at a prolific rate, sometimes more than one a year. Recently, Foreman set these aside to concentrate on film . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Night Life
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->ROCK AND POP<!--/goatcategory--> Musicians and night-club proprietors live complicated lives; it’s advisable to check in advance to confirm engagements.
<!--goatTitle-->B. B. KING BLUES CLUB & GRILL<!--/goatTitle--> 237 W. 42nd St. (212-997-4144)—April 18 and April 20: Shuggie Otis, the son of . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Movies
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPENING<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->DECEPTIVE PRACTICE: THE MYSTERIES AND MENTORS OF RICKY JAY<!--/goatTitle--> A documentary about the magician, directed by Molly Bernstein and Alan Edelstein. Opening April 17. (Film Forum.)
<!--goatTitle-->IN THE HOUSE<!--/goatTitle--> François Ozon directed this drama, about a bored teacher (Fabrice Luchini . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Dance
item.description: goatTitle-->BALLET HISPANICO<!--/goatTitle--> Since becoming artistic director, in 2009, Eduardo Vilaro has dusted off the company he inherited. Yet, in his quest to be contemporary, he’s shown questionable taste. His latest commission, “Sortijas,” is by Cayetano Soto, a Spanish choreographer in a familiar, twitchy, post . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Classical Music
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->OPERA<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN OPERA<!--/goatTitle--> April 19 and April 22 at 7: Finally, after helming three convincing but conventional productions for the Met, the Scottish director David McVicar shows us what he’s made of in his staging of “Giulio Cesare,” which d&#233 . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Art
item.description:
PageBreak --><!--goatcategory-->MUSEUMS AND LIBRARIES<!--/goatcategory-->
<!--goatTitle-->METROPOLITAN MUSEUM<!--/goatTitle--> Fifth Ave. at 82nd St. (212-535-7710)—“Impressionism, Fashion, and Modernity.” Through May 27. | “Photography and the American Civil War.” Through Sept. 2. | “African Art, New York, and the Avant-Garde.” Through Sept. 2 . . .

item.title: Goings on About Town: Above and Beyond
item.description: goatTitle-->LEBOWSKI FEST<!--/goatTitle--> This two-day party honoring the “The Big Lebowski,” the 1998 cult comedy by the Coen brothers, is a celebration of everything Lebowski. On the first day, at Gramercy Theatre, Los Duderinos, who are billed as the “ultimate metal Big Lebowski tribute band . . .

item.title: David Denby: Brian Helgeland’s “42” review.
item.description: Jackie Robinson had a heart-stopping way of taking a lead off third base. He didn’t drift a few feet off the bag and wait for the pitch, as most runners do. Facing the pitcher, he hopped sideways down the line, fluttering his fingers like a hummingbird&#8217 . . .
item.dc:creator: David Denby

item.title: Cora Frazier: “Apologies.”
item.description: President Obama late Thursday night called Kamala Harris, the California attorney general, and apologized to her for [saying] that she is the “best-looking attorney general in the country.” . . . [His spokesman] repeatedly remarked on Ms. Harris’s abilities, calling her “a remarkably effective leader as attorney . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Cora Frazier

item.title: Calvin Tomkins: Jasper Johns, foundation executive.
item.description: Quite a few people think that Jasper Johns is this country’s greatest living artist. Not too many are up on his career as a foundation executive. Since 1963, he has served as the chairman of the Foundation for Contemporary Arts, which has distributed more than ten million dollars . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Calvin Tomkins

item.title: Burkhard Bilger: A new era in Mars exploration.
item.description: There once were two planets, new to the galaxy and inexperienced in life. Like fraternal twins, they were born at the same time, about four and a half billion years ago, and took roughly the same shape. Both were blistered with volcanoes and etched with watercourses; both circled the same . . .
item.dc:creator: Burkhard Bilger

item.title: Books: Sarah Gristwood’s “Blood Sisters” review.
item.description: The Wars of the Roses are often remembered for the men who seized thrones and led battles, but in this lively history the women take the reins. Arguing persuasively for the existence of a “female network,” which shadowed and influenced that of the men, Gristwood details the paths . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: Jim Gavin’s “Middle Men” review.
item.description: The heroes of Gavin’s début story collection—male, manic, malcontent—are all California journeymen of one sort or another. They spend their lives “half-assing” and “coasting,” driving past “flatulent corridors of derelict foundries and abandoned railroad spurs&#8221 . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: Elif Shafak’s “Honor” review.
item.description: The sweeping title of this multigenerational novel refers to honor killing—a woman’s murder at the hands of her relatives or with their approval. Shafak follows a family’s journey from a small Kurdish village in the nineteen-forties to nineteen-nineties London, where her characters . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Books: David Berlinski’s “The King of Infinite Space” review.
item.description: This lively survey of the legacy of Euclid paints the geometer as “stern, logical, unrelenting, a man able to concentrate the powers of his mind on what is abstract and remote.” The axioms, theorems, proofs, and illustrations that fill Euclid’s “Elements” express the conviction . . . (Subscription required.)

item.title: Ben McGrath: Alaska’s Iditarod dynasties.
item.description: At 11:21 P.M. on the third day of this year’s Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race, Dallas Seavey, the reigning champion, rode into the village of Takotna, Alaska, standing behind the handlebars of a sled pulled by fourteen huskies, in rows of two. “Warm out,” he said . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Ben McGrath

item.title: Ben Greenman: A new album, “Small Town Talk,” from Shannon McNally and Dr. John.
item.description: paragraph class="noindent">The death of Bobby Charles, in 2010, touched off a resurgence of interest in the work of the Louisiana-born singer-songwriter. The standard obituaries focussed mainly on the swamp pop that Charles pioneered in the late fifties and early sixties; he wrote “See You Later . . .
item.dc:creator: Ben Greenman

item.title: Anthony Lane: Jean-Pierre Melville’s “Un Flic,” at Film Forum.
item.description: By the time Jean-Pierre Melville made “Un Flic,” in 1972, his style had condensed and cooled, beyond the elliptical, into near-abstraction. False backdrops abound; modern façades stretch away into the mist; a model helicopter hovers over a model train. Heists were by now familiar . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Anthony Lane

item.title: Anne Carson: “Short Talk on Herbology.”
item.description: The emperor considers his options. How he longed for the rhythm of campaigning, riding fast in foggy woods, riding slow eating chickpeas, accurate killing, little strange herbs of the frontier for his collection, little new bitter smells. He stood up. Arrest the envoys, he said . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Anne Carson

item.title: Alec Wilkinson: Nellie McKay clowns around in “Old Hats.”
item.description: One of Nellie McKay’s favorite parts of “Old Hats,” the revue by the master clowns Bill Irwin and David Shiner, of which she is the musical director and for which she is also listed as a featured performer, singing several songs, comes during the intermission, when . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Alec Wilkinson

item.title: Adam Gopnik: A hundred and twenty-five years of National Geographic.
item.description: Magazines in their great age, before they were unmoored from their spines and digitally picked apart, before perpetual blogging made them permeable packages, changing mood at every hour and up all night like colicky infants—magazines were expected to be magisterial registers of the passing scene. Yet, though they . . . (Subscription required.)
item.dc:creator: Adam Gopnik
